Award.AwardTitle: Creep of Temperature Stabilized Nanocrystalline Metals - a High Throughput Approach

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports fundamental research to map nanocrystalline metal creep, for which there is limited understanding, as a function of temperature and stress. High strength metals are used to reduce weight in many structural applications including aircraft and automobile components. Typically, metals are polycrystalline materials with grain size on the order of one hundred micrometers. One of the most effective methods to increase metal strength is to reduce the grain size to the nanometer scale. Such nanocrystalline metals are extremely strong at higher temperatures but typically suffer from creep at these temperatures. Thermally stabilized nanocrystalline metals are strong candidates for improved protective coatings, electrical contacts and are of great interest in nuclear material applications. This project will be beneficial for the training of graduate and undergraduate students in mechanical property evaluation, nanofabrication, electrodeposition and electron microscopy. Outreach activities will also be performed to develop YouTube videos relating fictional super powers of comic book characters to real-life materials enhancements.

A micromachined creep test platform has been developed and will be optimized. Objective one is to synthesize the first creep maps of nanocrystalline metals over a wide range of temperature and stresses. Previous work suggests that there is a threshold stress for secondary creep that scales inversely with grain size. Objective two is to investigate if this threshold stress exists and to explore its dependence on grain size. Objective three is to determine the underlying diffusion and dislocation-based mechanisms, in part through the use of transmission electron microscopy. In summary, this project endeavors to significantly improve the fundamental understanding of creep in nanocrystalline metals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Creep is the phenomenon that describes the elongation over time of structures that sustain stress.  In metals, creep falls into one of several regimes depending on  the ratio of temperature to melting temperature (T/Tm), and the ratio of shear stress to shear modulus (σs/G). Additionally, creep depends strongly on microstructural features such as grain size, alloy content and precipitate density.  As grain size decreases, metal strength theory predicts that metals become much stronger.  This observation has been validated by many researchers, with very strong metals being achieved with nanometer-scale grain size.  Nickel, used in many high temperature structural applications such as airplane engines, is a primary example. When the grain size of nickel is large, it creeps only when T/Tm is 0.4 or more, corresponding to 400 °C or more.  In fact, nickel alloys have been engineered to operate above 1000 °C. However, creep theories predict that metals with small grain size will exhibit creep even at room temperature, 25 °C. 

Another observation is that the grain size of nanocrystalline metals (nc-metals) is not retained when they are exposed to temperatures above room temperature. This is because the grains grow, and subsequently their inherent strength is lost. In recent years, researchers have found that if nc-metals are alloyed with other metals, they can retain their grain size to much higher temperatures, and hence their strength.  However, the issue of creep in these thermally stabilized nanocrystalline alloys, which are so far available only as films only micrometers in thickness, has received little attention.   

Nc-metals can potentially be engineered for simultaneous high temperature and high stress use. The intellectual merit of this project is two fold.  The first major contribution is to measure and understand creep of thermally stablilized nanocrystalline metals. An alloy of tungsten with nickel, nc Ni-W, is chosen to make these measurements. It is found that nc Ni-W creep at 450 °C is as low as pure nc-Ni creep at 120 °C. The creep regime is not that expected from basic creep theory, where a mechanism ascribed to diffusional flow of defects known as vacancies dominates.  Instead, the mechanism is attributed to microscopic defects known as dislocations. This measurement is performed on highly instrumented equipment known as high temperature nanoindentation. This equipment exists in only a few laboratories in the world and remains under development. 

The second major contribution is to develop a method by which creep can be more readily measured.  Here, the project has developed a micromechanical approach in which miniature tensile specimens are made using techniques similar to those used to fabricated electronic chips.  To do so, a new high temperature material which itself exhibits miniminal creep has been micromachined. This material is tantalum, a metal with a very high melting point, and it will apply the neeeded forces to the nanocrystalline specimens. Many specific problems related to micromachining of tantalum have been addressed and it has been demonstrated that actuators made from tantalum work.  This method can be reproduced in laboratories across the world that have basic micromachining capabilities.  

The broader impacts of this work include the advancement of our understanding the behavior of thermally stabilized nc-metals.  Such metals can be used as coatings to enhance the lifetime of structural materials. This will save energy and reduce cost of many materials.  A methods to evaluate nc metals more rapidly has also been developed.  Further, the project has partially supported three graduate students during the course of their PhD work.  Outreach included demonstrations to 6th-8th graders for visualizing small structures and understanding how they impact properties at the large scale.


Last Modified: 12/22/2019
Modified by: Maarten P De Boer

When the grain size of nickel is large, it creeps only when T/Tm is 0.4 or more, corresponding to 400 °C or more. In fact, nickel alloys have been engineered to operate above 1000 °C.
